comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Each year in my house we had the ceremony of the HAT!  My father would begin the process of buying a new hat and it took some weeks of trying on and deciding on what style and colour to wear.  He would have had a field day in this shop.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Wonder if he ever purchased a Falcon Make or a Battersby?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] He might have before I was born but if there was an Irish hat manfacturers then he would have gone for that.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I think the ancient art of hat wearing should be brought back to the country.  A good wide brimmed Fedora doubles as a personal umbrella on a wet day.

comment.author: 77603809@N02
comment._content: I must agree with Joefuz on that score. Hats are a much neglected accessory these days, except by the country music crowd.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: That's one thing missing these days, the fashionable hat. Men in old photos always looked so dapper with a fedora or what have you. They've all given way to the baseball cap...

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I admit to occasionally wearing a hat, and you get stared at the whole time.
